focus_skills: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units

questions.question: The graph of <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, where <math><mi>k</mi></math> is a constant, has its vertex on the <math><mi>x</mi></math>-axis. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: A parabola with vertex on the <math><mi>x</mi></math>-axis has exactly one real root, meaning its discriminant is zero. The discriminant of <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn></math> is <math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>36</mn></math>. Set equal to zero: <math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><msup><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math> → <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Only <math><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></math> appears as an option.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a quadratic to have its vertex on the x-axis, it must have exactly one real solution, so set the discriminant equal to zero.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='50' x2='50' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='370' y='260' font-size='14'>x</text><text x='30' y='40' font-size='14'>y</text><text x='50' y='270' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='150' y='270' font-size='12'>2</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='12'>4</text><text x='350' y='270' font-size='12'>6</text><text x='35' y='250' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='30' y='150' font-size='12'>10</text><text x='30' y='50' font-size='12'>20</text><circle cx='100' cy='60' r='5' fill='red'/><circle cx='150' cy='70' r='5' fill='red'/><circle cx='250' cy='110' r='5' fill='red'/><circle cx='350' cy='130' r='5' fill='red'/><line x1='50' y1='40' x2='370' y2='136' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot showing four data points with a clear negative linear trend. The x-axis ranges from 0 to 6. The y-axis ranges from 0 to 20. The points start high on the left (around y=19) and go lower to the right (around y=12).
questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between variables <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>y</mi></math>. Which of the following is closest to the slope of the line of best fit?
questions.explanation: The line of best fit passes near the points <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo></math> on the graph. The slope is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>18</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1.5</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='50' x2='50' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='370' y='260' font-size='14'>x</text><text x='30' y='40' font-size='14'>y</text><text x='50' y='270' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='150' y='270' font-size='12'>2</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='12'>4</text><text x='350' y='270' font-size='12'>6</text><text x='35' y='250' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='30' y='150' font-size='12'>10</text><text x='30' y='50' font-size='12'>20</text><circle cx='100' cy='60' r='5' fill='red'/><circle cx='150' cy='70' r='5' fill='red'/><circle cx='250' cy='110' r='5' fill='red'/><circle cx='350' cy='130' r='5' fill='red'/><line x1='50' y1='40' x2='370' y2='136' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><circle cx='150' cy='70' r='8' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><circle cx='350' cy='130' r='8' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><text x='160' y='65' font-size='12' fill='green'>(2, 18)</text><text x='300' y='150' font-size='12' fill='green'>(6, 12)</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same scatterplot with the points (2,18) and (6,12) circled in green to show the slope calculation coordinates.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To estimate the slope of a line of best fit, pick two points that lie clearly on the line (not necessarily data points) and use the slope formula.

questions.question: For <math><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>, which expression is equivalent to <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>8</mn></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math>?
questions.explanation: Simplify using exponent rules: <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>8</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>·</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Then <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. So the equivalent expression is <math><mn>1</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When simplifying exponential expressions, combine exponents by adding them, paying close attention to signs and fractions.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question:
A system of equations and its graph are shown.
y=2x+1
y=-x+7
What is the solution (x,y) to the system?
questions.explanation: Set the right-hand sides equal: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Add <math><mi>x</mi></math> to both sides: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. Subtract 1: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Divide by 3: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Substitute into either equation: <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. The solution is <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To solve a system of equations graphically, find the intersection point. Algebraically, set the expressions for y equal to each other.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='50' x2='50' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='370' y='260' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>Time (h)</text><text x='30' y='40' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>Bacteria (thousands)</text><text x='50' y='270' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>0</text><text x='150' y='270' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>2</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>4</text><text x='350' y='270' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>6</text><text x='35' y='250' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>0</text><text x='30' y='150' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>5</text><text x='25' y='50' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>10</text><circle cx='50' cy='230' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='100' cy='220' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='150' cy='205' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='200' cy='182' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='250' cy='150' r='4' fill='black'/><path d='M 50,230 Q 150,210 250,150 T 350,25' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot showing bacteria population (in thousands) over time (in hours). The points start at (0, 1) and rise exponentially, passing through (2, 2.25) and (4, 5). A blue curve of best fit tracks these points.
questions.question: A scientist measures the population of a bacteria culture every 2 hours. The scatterplot shows the data, and an exponential model of the form <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>t</mi></msup></math> is fitted, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi></math> is the population in thousands and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> is time in hours. Based on the model, what is the predicted population when <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The model appears to pass near <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Using <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>0</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi></math>, so <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Using <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math>: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></math> → <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> → <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mroot><mn>5</mn><mn>4</mn></mroot><mo>≈</mo><msup><mn>5</mn><mrow><mn>0.25</mn></mrow></msup><mo>≈</mo><mn>1.495</mn></math>. Then for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>·</mo><msup><mn>1.495</mn><mn>5</mn></msup><mo>≈</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>·</mo><mn>7.47</mn><mo>≈</mo><mn>7.5</mn></math> thousand.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='350' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='50' x2='50' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='370' y='260' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>Time</text><text x='30' y='40' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>Pop.</text><text x='50' y='270' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>0</text><text x='150' y='270' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>2</text><text x='250' y='270' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>4</text><text x='350' y='270' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>6</text><text x='35' y='250' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>0</text><text x='35' y='150' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>5</text><text x='35' y='50' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>10</text><circle cx='50' cy='230' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='100' cy='220' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='150' cy='205' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='200' cy='182' r='4' fill='black'/><circle cx='250' cy='150' r='4' fill='black'/><path d='M 50,230 Q 150,210 250,150 T 350,25' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><circle cx='50' cy='230' r='6' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><circle cx='250' cy='150' r='6' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><text x='60' y='225' font-size='12' fill='green'>(0,1)</text><text x='260' y='140' font-size='12' fill='green'>(4,5)</text><line x1='300' y1='250' x2='300' y2='100' stroke='red' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='300' y2='100' stroke='red' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><circle cx='300' cy='100' r='5' fill='red'/><text x='305' y='95' font-size='12' fill='red'>t=5, P=7.5</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The scatterplot with points (0,1) and (4,5) highlighted in green. A red dashed line indicates the prediction at t=5, showing the population value of 7.5 on the curve.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For exponential models of the form y = a*b^x, use given points to solve for a and b, then extrapolate to find predictions.

questions.question: What is the sum of the distinct real solutions to the equation <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>13</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Let <math><mi>u</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Then the equation becomes <math><msup><mi>u</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>13</mn><mi>u</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>u</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. So <math><mi>u</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> or <math><mi>u</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Then <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math> gives <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. The distinct real solutions are <math><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Their sum is <math><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For equations in quadratic form (like ax^4 + bx^2 + c = 0), use substitution u = x^2 to turn it into a quadratic equation.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,250 250,250 100,100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='100' y='230' width='20' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='80' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>C</text><text x='260' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>B</text><text x='80' y='95' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>A</text><text x='80' y='180' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>8</text><text x='180' y='170' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>10</text><path d='M 100,140 A 40,40 0 0,0 125,125' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='110' y='160' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>θ</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Right triangle ABC with the right angle at C. Vertex A is at the top, and Vertex B is to the right. Side AC (vertical) has length 8. Side AB (hypotenuse) has length 10. Angle A is labeled theta.
questions.question: In right triangle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> above, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. What is the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: In right triangle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, with right angle at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi></math>, side <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> is adjacent to angle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>θ</mi></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> is the hypotenuse. First, find side <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> (the opposite side) using the Pythagorean theorem: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><msup><mi>AB</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>AC</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mn>100</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>64</mn></mrow></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>36</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>opposite</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>adjacent</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>6</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,250 250,250 100,100' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='100' y='230' width='20' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='80' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>C</text><text x='260' y='265' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>B</text><text x='80' y='95' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>A</text><text x='80' y='180' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>8 (Adj)</text><text x='180' y='170' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>10 (Hyp)</text><path d='M 100,140 A 40,40 0 0,0 125,125' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='110' y='160' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif'>θ</text><text x='160' y='270' font-size='14' font-family='sans-serif' fill='red'>BC = 6 (Opp)</text><line x1='100' y1='253' x2='250' y2='253' stroke='red' stroke-width='2'/></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same triangle with the bottom side BC highlighted in red and labeled as 6 (Opposite).
questions.score_improvement_tip: In a right triangle, remember SOH-CAH-TOA. Identify which sides are opposite and adjacent relative to the angle in question before applying the tangent ratio.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, where <math><mi>m</mi></math> and <math><mi>b</mi></math> are constants. If <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> and <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Since <math><mi>f</mi></math> is linear, the slope <math><mi>m</mi></math> is constant. <math><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>19</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>9</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Using <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>: <math><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math> → <math><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math> → <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. So <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Then <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>28</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For linear functions, the rate of change (slope) is constant. Use two known points to find the slope and y-intercept, then evaluate at the desired input.

questions.question: A store initially priced a jacket at <math><mi>$</mi><mn>80</mn></math>. During a sale, the price was reduced by <math><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. After the sale, the price was increased by <math><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the sale price. What is the final price of the jacket?
questions.explanation: Sale price after 25% reduction: <math><mn>80</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0.25</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>. Or <math><mn>80</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.75</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>. Price after 25% increase on the sale price: <math><mn>60</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.25</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>75</mn></math>. Or <math><mn>60</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1.25</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>75</mn></math>. Final price is <math><mi>$</mi><mn>75</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that percent increases and decreases are applied sequentially to the current value, not the original value. A 25% decrease followed by a 25% increase does not return to the original price.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. For what value of <math><mi>x</mi></math> does <math><mi>f</mi></math> attain its minimum value?
questions.explanation: The function is <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Find the derivative: <math><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Set <math><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. The cubic has a positive leading coefficient, so as x increases, f decreases to a local minimum at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> then increases. Thus <math><mi>f</mi></math> attains a local minimum at <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For polynomial functions, local minima occur where the derivative changes from negative to positive. For cubics with positive leading coefficient, the rightmost critical point is typically a local minimum.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The mean of a set of 5 numbers is 12. If one number is removed, the mean of the remaining 4 numbers is 10. What is the value of the number that was removed?
questions.explanation: Let the sum of the 5 numbers be <math><mi>S</mi></math>. Then <math><mi>S</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, so <math><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>. After removing a number <math><mi>x</mi></math>, the sum of the remaining 4 numbers is <math><mi>S</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></math>, and their mean is <math><mn>10</mn></math>, so <math><mo>(</mo><mi>S</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>/</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mi>S</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn></math> → <math><mn>60</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the definition of mean: mean = sum / count. Set up equations for the sum before and after removing the number.

questions.question: A right circular cylinder has a height of 10 and a base radius of 3. What is the volume of the cylinder?
questions.explanation: Volume of a cylinder: <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>h</mi></math>. Here <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. So <math><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><msup><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the volume formula for a cylinder: V = πr²h. Ensure you square the radius before multiplying by π and height.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the solution set to the inequality <math><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>7</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract 3 from both sides: <math><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Divide both sides by -2, remembering to reverse the inequality sign: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When dividing or multiplying both sides of an inequality by a negative number, you must reverse the direction of the inequality sign.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: If 4 printers can print 400 pages in 4 hours, how many pages can 6 printers print in 6 hours at the same rate?
questions.explanation: First, find the rate per printer per hour: 400 pages / (4 printers * 4 hours) = 400/16 = 25 pages per printer-hour. So one printer prints 25 pages in one hour. With 6 printers for 6 hours: 6 printers * 6 hours * 25 pages/printer-hour = 36 * 25 = 900 pages.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For combined work problems, find the unit rate (work per time per worker), then scale up.

questions.question: If <math><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi></math> is a constant, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the numerator and denominator: <math><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac></math>. For <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, we can cancel <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, leaving <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>. Comparing to <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>, we have <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When simplifying rational expressions, factor both numerator and denominator completely, then cancel common factors (excluding values that make the denominator zero).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='80' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><line x1='120' y1='150' x2='280' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='200' y2='70' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='200' y='130' width='20' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='205' y='165' font-size='14'>O</text><text x='290' y='155' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='105' y='155' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='195' y='60' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='240' y='140' font-size='14'>8</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Circle with center O. Horizontal line segment AB is a diameter passing through O. Line segment OC is a vertical radius perpendicular to OA. The length of the radius is labeled as 8.
questions.question: In the figure above, circle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>O</mi></math> has a radius of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>8</mn></math>. Points <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi></math> lie on the circle such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is a diameter and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>O</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is perpendicular to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>O</mi><mi>A</mi></math>. What is the length of arc <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><mo>⌢</mo></mover></math>?
questions.explanation: Since <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is a diameter, angle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. Since <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>O</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>⊥</mo><mi>O</mi><mi>A</mi></math>, angle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The measure of arc <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is equal to the central angle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, which is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The circumference of the circle is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. The length of arc <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is the fraction of the circumference corresponding to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>Arc Length</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>90</mn><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>16</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>16</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='80' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><line x1='120' y1='150' x2='280' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='200' y2='70' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><rect x='200' y='130' width='20' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='205' y='165' font-size='14'>O</text><text x='290' y='155' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='105' y='155' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='195' y='60' font-size='14'>C</text><path d='M 280,150 A 80,80 0 0,0 200,70' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='4'/><text x='250' y='100' font-size='14' fill='red'>Arc AC = 4π</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same circle with the arc from A to C highlighted in red. The text 'Arc AC = 4 pi' is added to indicate the solution.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Arc length is a fraction of the circumference. Use the formula: (Central Angle / 360) * 2 * pi * r.

questions.question: What is the y-intercept of the line with equation <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: To find the y-intercept, set <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Then <math><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> → <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. So the y-intercept is <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: The y-intercept occurs where x=0. Substitute x=0 into the equation and solve for y.

questions.question: A bag contains 4 red marbles, 5 blue marbles, and 6 green marbles. If two marbles are drawn at random without replacement, what is the probability that both marbles are blue?
questions.explanation: Total marbles = 4+5+6 = 15. Probability first marble is blue = 5/15 = 1/3. After removing one blue, there are 4 blue left out of 14 total. Probability second marble is blue = 4/14 = 2/7. Multiply: (1/3)*(2/7) = 2/21.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For 'without replacement' probability problems, multiply the probabilities of each event, adjusting the total and favorable counts after each draw.

questions.question:
If (x,y) is a solution to the system of equations below, what is the value of x2+y2?
x+y=7
xy=12
questions.explanation: We are given <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Use the identity <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>. Substitute: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>24</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For symmetric systems, look for ways to combine equations to find x^2+y^2 directly, often using the identity (x+y)^2 = x^2+2xy+y^2.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 200,80' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='95' y='195' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='305' y='205' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='205' y='75' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='205' y='215' font-size='14'>D</text><line x1='200' y1='80' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='4,4'/><rect x='200' y='190' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='140' y='140' font-size='14'>10</text><text x='150' y='215' font-size='14'>6</text><text x='250' y='215' font-size='14'>8</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle ABC. An altitude CD is drawn from C to side AB. Side AC is labeled 10. The segment AD is labeled 6, and the segment DB is labeled 8.
questions.question: In triangle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> above, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is an altitude to side <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>. If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, what is the area of triangle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Given <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. In right triangle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, we can find <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi></math> using the Pythagorean theorem: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>A</mi><msup><mi>C</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>A</mi><msup><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mn>100</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>36</mn></mrow></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>64</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. The base <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math>. The area of triangle <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>C</mi><mi>D</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>56</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='100,200 300,200 200,80' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='95' y='195' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='305' y='205' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='205' y='75' font-size='14'>C</text><line x1='200' y1='80' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='red' stroke-width='2'/><text x='205' y='140' font-size='14' fill='red'>h=8</text><text x='150' y='215' font-size='14'>6</text><text x='250' y='215' font-size='14'>8</text><text x='140' y='140' font-size='14'>10</text><rect x='200' y='190' width='10' height='10' fill='none' stroke='black'/></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The triangle with the altitude calculated as 8 (highlighted in red). The total base is 14.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In problems with an altitude, consider if the smaller triangles formed are special right triangles (like 3-4-5 or 5-12-13) to find the height quickly.
